Congress has presently allocated $10.1-billion with another $50.8-billion pending for relief and recovery expenses.

 ~We will in fact need substantially more," said budget director Josh Bolten, estimating that the money would cover expenses for a few weeks.~
 
 I'm now reading estimates of $200-billion without costs of rebuilding NO or economic impact. Anyone care to take a guess at what the final tab will be?

May very well go above $200B, unless they ignore fixing the inherent problems to begin with. Reinforcing the levees is well and good, but 'tis a bandaid over an arterial wound.
 
 N'Orleans needs to be built above the water levels, and the Mississippi needs rediverted - back towards its more natural path.
 
 Any attempt to just rebuild NO in its prior image must be resisted tenaciously.

 If emotion politically manipulated by special interests such as Halliburton does persuade congress to rebuild NO, market force in the form of insurers may demand levees capable of withstanding Force 5 hurricanes. The alternative is a state disaster insurance fund similar to that in Florida where private insurers limit their exposure to premium revenue and the state has legislation enabling it to assess all state property owners for damage amounts exceeding the state insurance pool. LA doesn't possess the wealth of FL, so I don't know how feasible that bandaid would be. 
 
 Rational solutions, such as rebuilding NO above sea level and diversion of the Mississippi River generally fold when confronted by irrational emotion fanned by politicians. Hopefully the public displays common sense on this issue, but our record on that subject is not good. The cost of NO toxic clean-up alone could boggle the mind.
